Award.AwardTitle: NPGI: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2013. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow, who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Rick Masonbrink is "Investigating Centromere Evolution in Diploid and Polyploid plants in the Cotton Genus, Gossypium." The host institution for the fellowship is Iowa State University and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Jonathan Wendel.

This project focuses on the evolution of centromeres and the mysteries that surround centromere function after a chromosome complement saltationally becomes doubled due to polyploidy. By identifying centromere sequences in the progenitor diploid genomes and analyzing the fate of these diverged sequences in a phylogenetically characterized suite of allopolyploid cottons, the research will address how centromere repeats rapidly homogenize within and among chromosomes in diploids, and shed light on the evolutionary dynamics of centromere evolution during allopolyploid stabilization and subsequent speciation. This research will result in a greater understanding of centromeres and their function in plants, and represents an important but largely unexplored dimension of allopolyploid evolutionary genomics.

Training objectives include bioinformatics, phylogenetics, high-throughput genomics, next-generation sequencing, and chromatin immunoprecipitation. Broader impacts include outreach, scientific training, and mentoring of students at all levels, with the inclusion of underrepresented groups. Of particular note is a summer internship for middle school and high school educators for which the fellow will create and deliver a cytogenetics module intended to enrich teacher experiences and provide opportunities for curricular change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The centromere/kinetochore complex is a core structure necessary for cell division, a highly conserved process across eukaryotes. Yet the integral connection between the centromere and kinetochore is composed of rapidly evolving DNA sequences and proteins.  To gain a greater understanding of this relationship, both the centromeric protein and its binding DNA were characterized across a clade of diploid and polyploid species.  Specifically, this investigation assessed the consequences of merging two different regimes of centromeres into the same nucleus, and the events subsequent to speciation.  This research has led to the discovery that centromeres exchange DNA sequences bi-directionally, but not necessarily in an accurate manner. A large number of diverse centromeric DNA repeats were found, some of which carry foreign DNA fragments.  These fragments may illuminate the affinity for certain DNA structures that have a role in or affinity for centromere/kinetochore assembly   While centromeric sequences are not necessary for centromeric function, the DNA sequences were numerous and diverse, while these centromeric proteins were among the fastest evolving in the genome. As  a result of this study, a greater knowledge of centromere evolution and diversity  has been attained, a platorm from which new technologies can develop.  Some specific applications of this research lies with the development of artificial chromosomes that can be used for gene integration and expression, as well as for the production of more fertile, higher producing plant hybrids through the production of doubled haploids.
